awd_titl_txt: Mechanism of Asymmetric Growth of the Bacterial Plant Pathogen Agrobacterium tumefaciens
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacterial cells grow through expansion of their cell walls. Since the bacterial cell wall is an important antibiotic target and triggers immune responses, understanding bacterial growth is of broad fundamental interest. The proposed work will reveal the molecular mechanisms underlying growth of the plant pathogen, Agrobacterium tumefaciens. A. tumefaciens is the causative agent of crown gall disease in hundreds of flowering plants and is a particular problem for nursery plants such as apple, plum, and cherry. Remarkably, A. tumefaciens exhibits an atypical form of bacterial growth, in which new growth is restricted to one end of the cell (asymmetric growth). Asymmetric bacterial cell growth is relatively poorly understood, but has been observed frequently in diverse soil dwelling bacteria. Thus, the proposed scientific work is expected to provide key insights regarding mechanisms of bacterial growth, which may lead to important applications such as limiting crown gall disease. Finally, in collaboration with experts in science education, a hands-on, inquiry based lab module on the emergence of antibiotic resistance in bacteria will be developed. This module will provide high school students with an opportunity to participate in research and will provide an understanding of evolutionary processes.

Many important questions remain about the mechanism and regulation of cell wall biogenesis. How is cell wall biogenesis controlled in time and space? How are cell lengths and widths maintained? These questions have been primarily addressed in model bacteria, such as Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, which utilize a dispersed mode of cell wall growth. Expanding the analysis of bacterial cell growth into organisms with asymmetric growth will reveal new mechanisms for the biosynthesis, assembly, and regulation of cell wall biogenesis. In this project, the objective is to elucidate the mechanisms underlying unipolar growth of bacteria belonging to the Rhizobiales clade of Alphaproteobacteria using A. tumefaciens as a model. The following questions will be used to guide this work. How is cell wall biogenesis restricted to the new pole during elongation? How is cell wall biogenesis redirected to mid-cell to enable cell division and prime the new poles to serve as active sites for cell wall biogenesis? Recent advances in imaging cell wall biogenesis will be used to probe the mechanism of unipolar growth. Using a systematic approach, the role of candidate proteins in the biosynthesis, assembly, or regulation of cell wall biogenesis will be characterized. Genetic screens will be utilized to reveal additional proteins involved in bacterial cell growth processes. The proposed studies will improve the current understanding of how cell wall biogenesis is spatially and temporally regulated and will provide key insights into a relatively unexplored, but prevalent mode of bacterial cell growth.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Most bacteria produce a rigid, protective layer of sugars and peptides called the cell wall. While the structure and function of the bacterial cell wall are well conserved, the mechanisms responsible for cell wall biosynthesis during cell growth are variable. It is increasingly clear that rod-shaped bacteria use a diverse array of growth strategies with distinct spatial zones of cell wall biosynthesis, including lateral elongation, unipolar growth, bipolar elongation, and medial elongation. Yet much of our understanding regarding bacterial elongation is derived from a small number of model organisms exhibiting lateral elongation. Here, we sought to narrow our gap in knowledge about unipolar growth within the Rhizobiales clade of Alphaproteobacteria, using Agrobacterium tumefaciens as a model bacterium.

Agrobacterium tumefaciens is a plant pathogen and biotechnology powerhouse and yet little is known about its basic cell biology. To close this gap, our research team has developed genetic approaches to study essential processes in this emerging model bacterium. Furthermore, we have collaborated on the development of fluorescent probes to visualize cell wall biogenesis mediated by pencillin binding proteins (PBPs) in vivo. Our research has yielded many important insights which expand our understanding of bacterial growth. One of our major findings was the discovery that A. tumefaciens relies solely on a single PBP to direct polar growth. We have begun to characterize scaffolding proteins that target this PBP to the growth pole and regulators of its activity. While some proteins are conserved across bacteria, our results suggest that new regulatory relationships have evolved to enable spatiotemporal targeting of growth and division machinery. Moreover, we have expanded the scope of our studies to understand the response of A. tumefaciens to disruption of cell wall biogenesis genetically or chemically using cell wall targeting antibiotics. These studies have revealed the importance of inducible antibiotic resistance pathways and more general stress responses in conferring a high level of antibiotic resistance to A. tumefaciens. Collectively, our studies suggest that the mechanisms of polar growth and cell division have evolved through the expansion, diversification, and altered regulation of the core cell wall synthesis machinery in the Rhizobiales. 

 

Broader Impacts. An improved understanding of Agrobacterium tumefaciens growth mechanisms has the potential to inform best practices within an agriculture, particularly in the areas of crop protection and disease management. Improved agricultural practices are critical as both climate change and population growth challenge global food security.

Beyond the direct broader impacts of the research, our collaborative team has designed a curriculum unit to address socio-scientific issues in high school biology courses using antibiotic resistance, natural selection, and modeling. This guided investigation makes basic microbiology concepts and techniques accessible to students in a high school classroom. We developed models that align with the practices of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The models, together with the lab, are used to guide students through the process of argumentation using a claim, evidence, and reasoning (CER) format to explain the evolutionary mechanisms of antibiotic resistance. We continue to provide strains annually to interested teachers across the United States who want to implement this curriculum.
